Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Teaching Fellows in STEM High School Education: An Environmental Science Learning Community at the Land-Lake Ecosystem Interface

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
GRADUATE TEACHING FELLOWS IN K-12 EDUCATION
ABSTRACT

PROPOSAL #: 0742395
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Stepien, Carol
INSTITUTION: University of Toledo
TITLE: Graduate Teaching Fellows in STEM High School Education: An Environmental Science Learning Community at the Land-Lake Ecosystem Interface

The proposed program, ?Graduate Teaching Fellows in STEM High School Education: An Environmental Science Learning Community at the Land-Lake Ecosystem Interface? partners advanced graduate students at the University of Toledo and nearby University of Windsor with high school teachers and their students to build an Environmental Science Learning Community at the land-lake ecosystem interface. The objectives are to: 1) Generate student enthusiasm for science careers by engaging them in hands-on research into environmental problems, 2) Exchange knowledge and pedagogies between graduate students and high school teachers resulting in cutting-edge environmental science content and increased teaching and communication skills, and 3) Develop hands-on solutions to environmental problems along schoolyard stream ecosystems feeding the Great Lakes. Graduate fellows, teachers, and high school students will gain hands-on experience in the role of urban and agricultural influences on watersheds in the history, social development, and future vitality of the Great Lakes region; disseminated through the project website, presentations, and publications. Research on environmental problems is a real method through which students can give back to their own local communities, thereby helping to build an educational network focused on making lifestyles more interactive with the natural environment. This program thus embraces the public scholarship philosophic concept of merging scientific research with civic responsibility to benefit the public and the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF GK-12 Program, Graduate Teaching Fellows in STEM High School Education: An Environmental Science Learning Community at the Land-Lake Ecosystem Interface completed its final (seventh) year, capped by two years of no-cost extension continuation. This program operated through the University of Toledo’s Lake Erie Center across an urban-suburban-rural watershed gradient. Features included:

A) Schoolyard stream sampling for water quality, macroinvertebrates, and fishes,

B) Mentoring high school students in independent research, including science fairs, and

C) Learning community activities to provide shared environmental education along the watershed theme to teachers and graduate students. These are detailed on our program website at: http://www.utoledo.edu/nsm/lec/gk12_grant.

Annual program themes and content emphases was:
Year 1: Water quality and macroinvertebrate identification
Year 2: Geology, stream processes, and contaminants of the land-lake interface
Year 3: Impacts of a thermal plume on the environment
Year 4: Evolutionary and ecological adaptation of aquatic communities
Year 5: Integration with our environmental sensor network
Years 6 & 7: Continued hands on, inquiry based lessons and projects

Our program output included 344 conference presentations, 69 synergistic activities, and 84 publications. This award supported 15 Ph.D. students and 16 M.S. students, who spanned 4 academic departments (Environmental Sciences, Civil Engineering, Chemical and Environmental Engineering, and Geography and Planning) through the involvement of 17 graduate advisors. We mentored over 2500 high school students in 10 area high schools, and supported 11 teachers.

The high school students developed their STEM skills and exposure to careers via classroom activities, schoolyard stream monitoring, and research projects, and interfaced with a broader Environmental Science Learning Community. Students gained enriched learning experiences that led to greater understanding of nature and science inquiry, and their integration as a means of exploring the world. They engaged in hands-on environmental research and use of cyberinfrastructure in their individual science fair projects and classroom activities, mentored by the fellows. We mentored high school students in 149 district science fair projects; 34 of these projects received a superior rating, 25 won sponsored awards, and 5 advanced to the state competition.

This GK-12 program linked collaborative watershed research projects and built on an existing high school Student Watershed Watch program (SWW, http://tmacog.org/sww.htm) run by the Toledo Metropolitan Area Council of Governments (TMACOG). Participation engaged high school students to learn about the ecology of their local “schoolyard” streams through monitoring water quality and macroinvertebrates from a stream near their high school. Our GK-12 graduate fellows demonstrated to the students how to collect, analyze, and interpret their own stream data, which the high school students then presented at an annual Summit to raise awareness about local stream habitats and water quality. We are continuing this effort through interfacing with TMACOG as the NSF discontinued the entire GK-12 program, after allowing us to complete our plan. Further details are at: http://www.utoledo.edu/nsm/lec/gk12_grant.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Our NSF GK-12 Program, Graduate Teaching Fellows in STEM High School Education: An Environmental Science Learning Community at the Land-Lake Ecosystem Interface completed its final (seventh) year, capped by two years of no-cost extension continuation. This program operated through the University of ToledoÆs Lake Erie Center across an urban-suburban-rural watershed gradient. Features included: A) Schoolyard stream sampling for water quality, macroinvertebrates, and fishes, B) Mentoring high school students in independent research, including science fairs, and C) Learning community activities to provide shared environmental education along the watershed theme to teachers and graduate students. These are detailed on our program website at: http://www.utoledo.edu/nsm/lec/gk12_grant. Annual program themes and content emphases was: Year 1: Water quality and macroinvertebrate identification Year 2: Geology, stream processes, and contaminants of the land-lake interface Year 3: Impacts of a thermal plume on the environment Year 4: Evolutionary and ecological adaptation of aquatic communities Year 5: Integration with our environmental sensor network Years 6 & 7: Continued hands on, inquiry based lessons and projects Our program output included 344 conference presentations, 69 synergistic activities, and 84 publications. This award supported 15 Ph.D. students and 16 M.S. students, who spanned 4 academic departments (Environmental Sciences, Civil Engineering, Chemical and Environmental Engineering, and Geography and Planning) through the involvement of 17 graduate advisors. We mentored over 2500 high school students in 10 area high schools, and supported 11 teachers. The high school students developed their STEM skills and exposure to careers via classroom activities, schoolyard stream monitoring, and research projects, and interfaced with a broader Environmental Science Learning Community. Students gained enriched learning experiences that led to greater understanding of nature and science inquiry, and their integration as a means of exploring the world. They engaged in hands-on environmental research and use of cyberinfrastructure in their individual science fair projects and classroom activities, mentored by the fellows. We mentored high school students in 149 district science fair projects; 34 of these projects received a superior rating, 25 won sponsored awards, and 5 advanced to the state competition. This GK-12 program linked collaborative watershed research projects and built on an existing high school Student Watershed Watch program (SWW, http://tmacog.org/sww.htm) run by the Toledo Metropolitan Area Council of Governments (TMACOG). Participation engaged high school students to learn about the ecology of their local "schoolyard" streams through monitoring water quality and macroinvertebrates from a stream near their high school. Our GK-12 graduate fellows demonstrated to the students how to collect, analyze, and interpret their own stream data, which the high school students then presented at an annual Summit to raise awareness about local stream habitats and water quality. We are continuing this effort through interfacing with TMACOG as the NSF discontinued the entire GK-12 program, after allowing us to complete our plan. Further details are at: http://www.utoledo.edu/nsm/lec/gk12_grant. The annual capstone signature event of our GK-12 program was a high school student poster show featuring student research projects, held at the Lake Erie Center each spring. This further interfaced the high school teachers, students, and fellows with the Environmental Science Learning Community members and our university faculty and administrators. The Learning Community facilitated extending our program for two additional years with GK-12 graduate fellows supported as University teaching assistants from three departments.
